dc:description: ​The IKZF1 gene encodes ​the protein IKAROS. The first report of IKAROS deficiency was described in 2012 in a patient suffering pancytopenia (Goldman et al, 2012; PMID: 21548011). This report described the ​importance of ​the IKZF1 gene as a crucial transcription factor for hematopoiesis with relevance in immune development. IKAROS deficiency is a heterogeneous disease characterized by lymphopenia, hypogammaglobulinemia, immune dysregulation, and depending on the mechanism of disease, it can confer common variable immunodeficiency, combined immunodeficiency, or immune dysregulation. According to the criteria outlined by the ClinGen Lumping and Splitting Working Group, ​the molecular mechanism of this disease can be described as loss of function, gain of function, or somatic. Furthermore, the loss of function and gain of function mutations have been split into two disease entities, pancytopenia due to IKZF1 mutations (MONDO: 0014810) and autoimmune diseases (MONDO:0007179), respectively. . The somatic mutations that have been associated with leukemias were not considered for this curation because they are beyond the scope of the Immunology Clinical Domain Working Group. Pancytopenia due to IKZF1 mutations (MONDO: 0014810) have been associated with the partial or complete loss of function of the IKAROS protein. A total of 13 variants (Missense, deletions or splicing) that have been reported in 22 probands in 6 publications (PMIDS: 21548011, 26981933, 27939403, 28096536, 29889099, 31069201) are included in this curation. The mechanism of pathogenicity is loss of function, which is typically determined based on the DNA binding capability of the IKAROS protein. This gene-disease association is also supported by experimental evidence, including impaired protein expression, homodimer formation, nuclear translocation and biochemical function of IKAROS protein in in vitro cell lines and patient´s cells (PMIDS: 21548011, 26981933, 27939403, 28096536, 29889099). IKZF1 heterozygous mutations cause a wide spectrum of clinical manifestations such as B cell lymphopenia, hypogammaglobulinemia, autoimmune manifestations and in some cases development of leukemia. The molecular mechanism evaluated by biochemical function is haploinsufficiency . The majority of patients with haploinsufficiency in IKAROS are diagnosed with common variable immunodeficiency. On the other hand, another molecular mechanism was described in 2018 (PMID: 29889099) in where a point mutation N159S or N159T cause a dominant negative effect causing a much severe clinical phenotype characterized by B cell lymphopenia,  T cell lymphopenia and myeloid differentiation defects. All patients carrying dominant negative variants had early onset with severe life threatening infections, these patient´s were diagnosed with combined immunodeficiency.   In summary, IKZF1 is definitively associated with pancytopenia due to ikaros mutations. This has been repeatedly demonstrated in both the research and clinical diagnostic settings, and has been upheld over time.

evidence.dc:description: Overexpression of the variant R162W was performed in NIH3T3 cell lines to evaluate the capability of nuclear translocation. Variant R162W showed loss of the punctate pericentromeric heterochromatin staining within the nucleus. Furthermore, using electrophoretic mobility shift assay it was confirmed that the variant R162W lost the DNA binding capability.
There are less than 4 segregations in this family

member.rdfs:label: Patient A.1
member.detectionMethod: PCR of all IKZF1 exons was performed using genomic DNA from patient and parents, DNA from MOLT-4 cells were used as control. Sanger sequencing of all exons was performed and patient´s DNA revealed an ambiguity at exon 5. To confirm the patient carried an heterozygous mutation  authors performed TOPOTA cloning and single colonies were sequenced proving that patient has heterozygous mutation: c.629A>G (p.Tyr210Cys) in IKZF1 gene

evidence.dc:description: Overexpression of the variant N159S was done in EHL293 cell line to evaluate the capability of nuclear translocation of IKZF1. Variant N159S showed loss of the punctate pericentromeric heterochromatin staining within the nucleus.

Overexpression of the variant Y210C was performed in NIH3T3 cell lines to evaluate the capability of nuclear translocation. Variant Y210C showed impaired punctate pericentromeric heterochromatin staining within the nucleus. Furthermore, using electrophoretic mobility shift assay it was confirmed that the variant Y210C has impaired DNA binding capability.
Overexpression assays in HEK293 cells demonstrated loss of DNA binding activity and diffuse localization in the nucleus.
Overexpression assays in HEK293 cells demonstrated loss of DNA binding activity and diffuse localization in the nucleus.
Overexpression assays in HEK293 cells demonstrated loss of DNA binding activity and diffuse localization in the nucleus.

Overexpression of the variant N159S was performed in NIH3T3 cell lines to evaluate the capability of nuclear translocation. Variant N159S showed loss of the punctate pericentromeric heterochromatin staining within the nucleus. Furthermore, using electrophoretic mobility shift assay it was confirmed that the variant N159S was unable to bind DNA.
Overexpression assays in HEK293 cells demonstrated loss of DNA binding activity and diffuse localization in the nucleus.

Overexpression of the variant R162Q was performed in NIH3T3 cell lines to evaluate the capability of nuclear translocation. Variant R162Q showed loss of the punctate pericentromeric heterochromatin staining within the nucleus. Furthermore, using electrophoretic mobility shift assay it was confirmed that the variant R162Q lost the DNA binding capability.

The mRNA was obtained from patient´s PBMCs and IKZF1 transcripts were clonned to obtain single transcripts, further sequencing confirmed deletions, insertions or both that are predicted to severily impaired the function of ZF2, ZF3, or ZF4
Overexpression assays in HEK293 cells demonstrated loss of DNA binding activity and diffuse localization in the nucleus.
Patient´s cells showed less expression of IKZF1 protein by flow cytometry.
Overexpression assays in HEK293 cells demonstrated loss of DNA binding activity and diffuse localization in the nucleus.
Overexpression assays in HEK293 cells demonstrated loss of DNA binding activity and diffuse localization in the nucleus.

Ikaros localization at pericentromeric heterochromatin (PC-HC) was evaluated in the patient's peripheral blood-derived mononuclear cells. Compared to his sister´s cells and Jurkat cell lines, the patient's cells exhibited an abnormal and diffuse nuclear localization of Ikaros protein. Moreover, overexpression of the mutant allele in HEK293T cells demonstrated that mutation  p.Tyr210Cys disrupts the DNA binding compared to WT Ikaros protein using 4 different proves by EMSA assays.
Overexpression assays in HEK293 cells demonstrated loss of DNA binding activity and diffuse localization in the nucleus.
There is no functional evidence that demostrates the variant H167R is loss of function.
Overexpression assays in HEK293 cells demonstrated loss of DNA binding activity and diffuse localization in the nucleus.

Overexpression of the variant C147R  in NIH3T3 cell lines demostrates that variant C147R loss of the punctate pericentromeric heterochromatin staining within the nucleus. Furthermore, using electrophoretic mobility shift assay it was confirmed that the variant C147R lost the DNA binding  capability.
Overexpression assays in HEK293 cells demonstrated loss of DNA binding activity and diffuse localization in the nucleus.
Overexpression assays in HEK293 cells demonstrated loss of DNA binding activity and diffuse localization in the nucleus.

Point mutation in H191R disrupts the DNA binding capability of IKAROS, Homozygous mice for this mutation are embryonic lethal and heterozygous mice can survive but they present severe lymphopenia, severe defects in terminal erythrocyte and granulocyte differentiation.
evidence.rdfs:label: IKAROS point mutation mice model.

evidence.dc:description: Dominant negative IKAROS mice show severe B cell lymphopenia, lack of NK which and susceptibility to develop leukemias these phenotypes are similar to the patients with heterozygous loss of function IKZF1 alleles.
evidence.rdfs:label: Dominant negative mice model

evidence.dc:description: IKAROS null mice models remarks the important role of IKAROS in hematopoiesis. Null mice show severe B cell lymphopenia, lack of NK which are similar phenotypes that have been observed for patients with heterozygous loss of function IKZF1 alleles.
evidence.rdfs:label: IKAROS -/- mouse model

evidence.dc:description: Immunophenotyping in PBMCs of patients carrying N159T and N159S mutation in IKZF1 showed severe B lymphopenia, affected T cell count and dendritic cell differentiation. Additionally, in these patients was found a profound hypogammaglobulinemia, impairment in T cell proliferation upon PHA and OKT3 stimulation and decreased cytokine production upon activation.
evidence.rdfs:label: Immunophenotyping: Impaired T , B & myeloid differentiatio

evidence.dc:description: NIH3T3 cells transfected with H195R variant can´t form punctual foci formation in the nucleus compared to the WT
evidence.rdfs:label: Pericentromeric heterocrhomatin staining

evidence.dc:description: Results showed that Ikaros proteins harboring the mutation observed in the patient have decreased DNA-binding affinity toward probes derived from human PC-HC when compared to the wild type Ikaros
evidence.rdfs:label: DNA binding capacity

evidence.dc:description: NIH3T3 cells transfected with N159T or N159S variants can´t form punctual foci formation in the nucleus. Moreover, cotransfection with 50% of WT IKZF1 demonstrates that variants N159T and N159S disrupts completely the migration of IKZF1 homodimers to the nucleus by a dominant negative effect.
evidence.rdfs:label: Dominant negative effect

evidence.dc:description: The molecular mechanism for loss of function variants: R162Q, R162L, H167R and R184Q is suggested to be haploinsufficiency. The clinical phenotype of these patients is not severe compared to the patient´s carrying dominant negative IKZF1 variants.
evidence.rdfs:label: IKZF1 dimerization

evidence.dc:description: IKZF1 is necesary for the differentiation of B cells. Loss of function variants impact the differentiation of B cells by happloinsuficiency mechanism.
evidence.rdfs:label: DNA binding capacity

evidence.dc:description: IKZF1 is important in hematopoiesis, loss of function variants have been proven to cause CVID. However, variants N159S and N159T in IKZF1 cause a much severe phenotype: combined immunodeficiency by dominant negative mechanism.
evidence.rdfs:label: DNA binding capacity

evidence.dc:description: Evidence suggests differences between novel variants: N159T and N159T and variants conferring CVID: R162Q, R162Q, H167R, R184Q or deletions. However, this experiment does not show differences between mutant and WT IKZF1

IKZF1 protein can form homodimers IKZF1-IKZF1, by overexpression system authors evaluated whether the mutants: N159S and N159T can form dimers with the WT IKZF1. Co Immunoprecipitation results showed that all mutants have the ability to form dimers with WT IKZF1 similar to the WT-WT interactions.
evidence.rdfs:label: IKZF1 dimerization

evidence.dc:description: T cells and B cells from patients showed decreased expression of IKZF1 protein by flow cytometry
evidence.rdfs:label: IKZF1 expression in T and B cells

evidence.dc:description: Peripheral blood-derived mononuclear cells from the patient were stained to investigate the localization of IKZF1 protein. Patient´s cells showed a difused IKZF1 localization compare to his sister and Jurkat cell line.
evidence.rdfs:label: IKZF1 localization in T cells
